subject: Law
title: The Fourth Amendment and Privacy
description: A fast breakdown of The Fourth Amendment and Privacy for builders.

hook.text: Police tracked a suspect's phone location for 127 days without a warrant. The Supreme Court called it a search.

buildup.text: The Fourth Amendment protects against 'unreasonable searches and seizures' and requires warrants.

discovery.text: In Carpenter v. United States (2018), the Court ruled digital location data needs a warrant.

twist.text: The founders never imagined smartphones. Courts must constantly adapt 18th-century words to modern tech.

climax.text: The 'reasonable expectation of privacy' test from Katz v. United States guides modern Fourth Amendment cases.

punchline.text: Privacy rights now follow you into your pocket.

quiz.question: What did Carpenter v. United States require for cell phone location data?
